contents.title: Welcome to my blog
contents.description: Welcome to my development blog where I share the things I’ve learned and found interesting.

children.value: Hi everyone, my name is Rafael Valenzuela, I’m a self-taught web developer and this is my blog about the things that I think are worth sharing about web development.

I’m currently working with Vue and Nuxt on the front end and the Django Rest Framework and Postgres for the backend. I’m doing this because sometimes I’ve found myself struggling to try to do something or fix a bug and the only way it works is mixing different things from different places (blog posts, youtube videos, etc) and I’d like to keep my version of this solutions and share them with anyone who can uses when needed and save some time.
I’d also like to share my thoughts about certain topics related to the tech field like trends or any other stuff.
That being said, I hope you can join my journey and read what I have to say in the next articles.

contents.title: How to setup Nuxt 3 with Tailwind CSS, Pinia and Supabase
contents.description: Learn how to create a boilerplate project in order to start your next project faster

children.value: in the past and you want to try the new
along with the new state management library
with the new composable, stay here in order to learn how to set up your new project correctly.
First up, we are going to open up our terminal to create our new
project and for that, we are going to type the following commando:

props.code: npx nuxi init appname

children.value: with the name of your actual application.
Now, as the installation says, we need to open the application folder and then we are going to open vscode with the following commands:

props.code:
cd appname
code .

children.value: because that means we are running the code editor in the current folder.
is opened and activated all your extensions, we need to install the dependencies of our application and for that we are going to use a package manager with one of the following commands:

props.code:
# yarn (Recommended)
yarn install

# npm
npm install

children.value: Now that we have our application’s dependencies installed, we are going to set up
and everything that it needs to run correctly.
and the related dependencies as a developer dependency:

props.code:
# yarn
yarn add --dev @nuxtjs/tailwindcss prettier prettier-plugin-tailwindcss

npm install -D @nuxtjs/tailwindcss prettier prettier-plugin-tailwindcss

children.value: Once it finishes, we need to run the following command in order to create our Tailwind config file:

props.code: npx tailwindcss init

children.value: We create a store by declaring a variable that will be exported using
before the name of the store for convention purposes and this will be equal to the imported
who receives two parameters: a string with the name of the store (to avoid duplicated stores) and an object:
Inside the object we can setup our
syntax by changing the second parameter for a call back arrow function and returning all the state and methods like this:

props.code:

contents.title: How to create a Django Rest Framework boilerplate project
contents.description: Learn how to create a boilerplate project in order to start your next project faster

children.value: When you start learning Web Development or any kind of software technology is quite hard to remember exactly the step-by-step process of doing things even the simplest ones like the initial setup of your project. That’s why I’m doing this post about creating a project boilerplate guide so I or anyone interested can follow it along when you start a new project.
In this case, I’m assuming that you already have python and pip installed on your computer.
First of all, we need to set up our virtual environment in order to install all of the dependencies inside of it instead of our local machine.
In your terminal we run the following command:

props.code: pip install virtualenv

children.value: Now we create a virtual environment:

props.code: virtualenv virtualenv_name

children.value: Keep in mind that virtualenv_name is where you have to put your virtual environment name
Then we run our just-created environment:

props.code: virtualenv_name\scripts\activate

children.value: It is important to use backslashes if you are using the windows command prompt rather than forward slashes to avoid any errors.
Once you do that you should see your terminal path with a ( virtualenv_name ) before and that means that your virtual environment is activated.
We can manually install Django and everything else one by one but I recommend creating a
file with all the things I need to install on the get go and then I install any dependency as needed later.
Your requirements.txt file should looks something like this:

props.code:
django==4.0.2
djangorestframework==3.13.1
django-cors-headers==3.11.0

children.value: I highly recommend doing a little research about the current version of your apps in order to avoid any issues in the future.
Now is the time to create our
project which is the base structure of our project.
In your terminal run the following command:

props.code: django-admin startproject project_name .

children.value: Keep in mind that there’s a dot at the end of the command that avoids creating a nested folder with everything inside so instead is creating the project on your current directory (you can actually put anything instead of the dot and that will create a new folder with all the project inside but I don’t do that because I called the root directory as the project name for convenience).
Once we do that we’ll end up with a
file which we’ll use to run our
App is the name used in
for every functionality within our project. In order to create our API app we need to run the following command:

props.code: django-admin startapp api

children.value: Now we need to register our app so our
can communicate with it and we do that by going to our
folder and we have to look for the
list and add our apps below the last one like this:

props.code:
INSTALLED_APPS = [
'django.contrib.admin',
'django.contrib.auth',
'django.contrib.contenttypes',
'django.contrib.sessions',
'django.contrib.messages',
'django.contrib.staticfiles',
'api.apps.ApiConfig',
‘rest_framework’
]

children.value: The next step I follow is creating our first view which would be a generic one with a list of our routes, I use class-based views so it should look like this:
The next step is to create a
file inside of our api app folder and add some basic structure:

props.code:
from django.urls import path
from .views import GetRoutes


urlpatterns = [
    path('', GetRoutes.as_view())
]

children.value: Include api urls in project_name urls.py
from django.urls but since we are using this already to import our
we can just add it along with it by adding a comma next, then we add our api path:

props.code:
from django.contrib import admin

from django.urls import path, include

urlpatterns = [
path('admin/', admin.site.urls),
path('api/', include('api.urls'))
]

children.value: Running our server for the first time
Now we are ready to give this a try but before we run our server we have to migrate our tables to our database first so we need to run the following command:

props.code: python manage.py migrate

children.value: Once it finishes we can run our server:

props.code: python manage.py runserver

children.value: If everything went correct, we should be able to open our server in our browser or Postman with this link:

props.code: http://localhost:8000/api

children.value: We should see a screen like this one:

And that’s it, now you’re ready to add everything else to your project. I hope that helps you as it will for me every time I want to create a new full-stack project. Thanks for reading and have a good one :).

Running our server for the first time

contents.title: How to setup user authentication with Django Rest Framework and JWT
contents.description: A simple setup of authentication with a custom model using Django Rest Framework and JWT

children.value: User authentication is one of the things that we repeat every time we create a new project and once you have finished your
is the next thing I use to set up if I need that functionality so with that said, we’ll see how you can create a custom user model including authentication endpoints with
First up, we are going to install
to be able to generate our authentication token that we need to send POST HTTP requests that need a user logged in.

props.code: pip install djangorestframework-simplejwt

children.value: Once we do that, we can use this library a bit later.
Now we need to open our

props.code:
# ...other imports
import timedelta

# ...settings code

AUTH_USER_MODEL = 'users.UserProfile'

REST_FRAMEWORK = {
    'DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_CLASSES': (
        'rest_framework_simplejwt.authentication.JWTAuthentication',
        )
}

SIMPLE_JWT = {
    'ACCESS_TOKEN_LIFETIME': timedelta(days=1),
    'REFRESH_TOKEN_LIFETIME': timedelta(days=30),
    'ROTATE_REFRESH_TOKENS': False,
    'BLACKLIST_AFTER_ROTATION': True,
    'UPDATE_LAST_LOGIN': False,

    'ALGORITHM': 'HS256',

    'VERIFYING_KEY': None,
    'AUDIENCE': None,
    'ISSUER': None,

    'AUTH_HEADER_TYPES': ('Bearer',),
    'AUTH_HEADER_NAME': 'HTTP_AUTHORIZATION',
    'USER_ID_FIELD': 'id',
    'USER_ID_CLAIM': 'user_id',
    'USER_AUTHENTICATION_RULE': 'rest_framework_simplejwt.authentication.default_user_authentication_rule',

    'AUTH_TOKEN_CLASSES': ('rest_framework_simplejwt.tokens.AccessToken',),
    'TOKEN_TYPE_CLAIM': 'token_type',

    'JTI_CLAIM': 'jti',

    'SLIDING_TOKEN_REFRESH_EXP_CLAIM': 'refresh_exp',
    'SLIDING_TOKEN_LIFETIME': timedelta(minutes=5),
    'SLIDING_TOKEN_REFRESH_LIFETIME': timedelta(days=1),
}

# ...more code

children.value: Once we’ve finished with our JWT setup, we need to go ahead and create our user app for our project. We do that by opening our terminal and running the following command:

props.code: django-admin start app users

children.value: That will create a new directory in our project with the necessary files and ready to be registered.
The next step is to add our newly created app. We open the
Now we are ready to create our custom user model. The first thing to do is to open the
file and import the base models from

props.code:
from django.db import models
from django.contrib.auth.models import AbstractBaseUser, PermissionsMixin, BaseUserManager

children.value: Then we create our first model which will be the user manager capable of creating our superusers and the regular users and will have two methods the

props.code:
class UserProfileManager(BaseUserManager):
    """Manager for user profiles"""

    def create_user(self, email, username, password=None):
        if not email:
            raise ValueError('Users must have an email')

        email = self.normalize_email(email)
        user = self.model(email=email, username=username)

        user.set_password(password)
        user.save(using=self._db)

        return user

    def create_superuser(self, email, username, password):
        user = self.create_user(email, username, password)

        user.is_superuser = True
        user.is_staff = True
        user.save(using=self._db)

children.value: method will create a new user in our database but first will validate if the email field is empty and will raise an error stating that the email is already registered, then we’ll set the
from the parameters, save them in our database and return the user at the end.
is more straightforward due to we are reusing all of the logic from our
and adding some extra properties like the
Now that we have our user manager model we can create our
model which will include all of the necessary fields for our user.
We need to create a class with
models that we imported earlier as parameters. We proceed to create the following fields:

props.code:
class UserProfile(AbstractBaseUser, PermissionsMixin):
    email = models.EmailField(max_length=255, unique=True)
    username = models.CharField(max_length=255, unique=True)
    avatar = models.URLField(blank=True, null=True)
    is_active = models.BooleanField(default=True)
    is_staff = models.BooleanField(default=False)

    objects = UserProfileManager()

    USERNAME_FIELD = 'username'
    REQUIRED_FIELDS = ['email']

    def __str__(self):
        return self.email

children.value: As you can see we created an object variable that is referencing our
model in order to use this for our ORM queries in our views later. Also, we declare a constant named
" in order to be able to log in with our username instead of the email.
Once we have our user model, we can create our serializer which is the way
data and vice versa by creating a file named
inside of our user folder. Inside the file we are going to start by importing

props.code:
from rest_framework import serializers
from .models import UserProfile

children.value: Then we need to create a class with the name of our model followed by the word
. Inside the class we need to create another class named
which is going to include the model we are serializing and the fields we want to show in our
where we are telling that the password field is “
”. Finally, we create a method that will create a new row in our database with the new user when we register a new one.
Now we are ready to create our views which are basically classes that run
queries and business logic inside when a URL has been called. We are going to start up by importing all the things we need

props.code:
from rest_framework.views import APIView
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework import status
from rest_framework.permissions import IsAuthenticated
from rest_framework.parsers import JSONParser, MultiPartParser, FormParser
from .models import UserProfile
from .serializers import UserProfileSerializer

children.value: Then we can create our first view which is going to be called
and we are going to pass
that was imported earlier. This - as the name states - is going to be the view we want to use when the
Inside our class, we are going to add our

variable which is going to be equal to the parsers we imported as well. Then we create a post method with the self and request parameters. Inside our method, we first are going to validate if the email has been already registered by searching for it in our database and raise an error if so, then we are going to serialize our data from our request, save the serializer and return a response with the serialized data and the corresponding
# if email is already in use
The second view we need is the
parameter which is going to return the authenticated user that makes the request excluding the password. Inside the class, we are going to add the
variable that is going to be equal to a tuple with the "
method is only going to serialize the user from the request also we are going to create a
method in order to be able to change our user avatar image. The code should look like this:
Finally, our last view is going to be the
permission class which is going to return all of our users and return the serialized response.
— You may be wondering why we didn’t create a login view and that’s because we are going to take care of that with
Now we are going to create a
file in order to create the endpoints for our
. First off, we are going to import the
and the views for creating our access token, and the refresh token from
Finally, we are going to create our
variable with the list of paths including the URL and the class view we are going to use for them.

props.code:
urlpatterns = [
    path('', AllUsersView.as_view()),
    path('user/', UserView.as_view()),
    path('register/', RegisterUserView.as_view()),
    path('token/', TokenObtainPairView.as_view(), name='token_obtain_pair'),
    path('token/refresh/', TokenRefreshView.as_view(), name='token_refresh'),
]

children.value: We can give it a try to the endpoints using
Now you can use this custom user and the authentication endpoints in your next project that needs authentication and save a lot of time. I hope this was helpful and don’t miss the next post about

contents.title: How to setup user authentication with Nuxt 3, Supabase and Tailwind CSS
contents.description: Add authentication to your Nuxt 3 application easyly with Supabase and restrict access to logged in users only

children.value: We sometimes need user authentication in our web application depending on the situation. In this article, we’ll see how to create a login and register pages with
authentication and a route middleware to avoid access to certain pages if we are not logged in.
I’m assuming that you’ve followed my previous
post about setting up your project with Tailwind and Supabase.
We start up by deleting the content of our
file or if you don’t have it you can create a
tag we are going to bring the destructured
and it should look like this:

props.code:
<script setup>
const { auth } = useSupabaseClient();
const user = useSupabaseUser();
</script>

children.value: Next, we are going to create a constant named
(you can call it however you like) which is going to be equal to an asynchronous arrow function and we are going to await the

props.code:
<script setup>
// Some code

const userLogout = async () => {
  await auth.signOut();
};
</script>

children.value: Validating if we are logged in
tag we are now going to validate if the user is logged in and redirect it to the login page if it’s not.

props.code:
<script setup>
// Some code

watchEffect(() => {
  if (!user.value) {
    return navigateTo('/login');
  }
});

definePageMeta({
  middleware: 'auth',
});
</script>

children.value: Altogether is going to look like this:

props.code:
<script setup>
const { auth } = useSupabaseClient();
const user = useSupabaseUser();

const userLogout = async () => {
  await auth.signOut();
};

watchEffect(() => {
  if (!user.value) {
    return navigateTo('/login');
  }
});

definePageMeta({
  middleware: 'auth',
});
</script>

children.value: The template tag inside the index page

Now we are ready to add some markup to show an interface that in this case is going to be a basic profile page showing a fake profile image with the logged-in email address and a button to logout with some
inline-flex h-20 w-20 items-center justify-center rounded-full bg-gray-800 text-gray-600
mt-2 mb-4 h-1 w-12 rounded bg-[#42b883]
mt-8 rounded-md bg-[#42b883] px-4 py-2 font-sans font-bold text-[#213547] transition-colors duration-500 hover:bg-[#42d392] focus:outline-none
In order to register a new user, we are going to create a new page called
tag. Inside the script, we are going to bring the
object again, and also we are going to define our state that is going to be the

props.code:
<script setup>
const user = useSupabaseUser();
const email = ref('');
const password = ref('');
const confirmPassword = ref('');
const errorMsg = ref('');

const { auth } = useSupabaseClient();
</script>

children.value: Next, we are going to create a constant named
which is going to be an asynchronous arrow function that is going to validate first if the

are the same, if they are not is going to display an error message and delete both fields. If they do, it’s going to run a try-catch block that is going to await the signUp method from auth with our email and password state values and clear the input fields or display an error message if there are any errors.

props.code:
<script setup>
// Some code

const userRegister = async () => {
  if (password.value !== confirmPassword.value) {
    errorMsg.value = 'Passwords do not match!';
    password.value = '';
    confirmPassword.value = '';
    setTimeout(() => {
      errorMsg.value = '';
    }, 3000);
    return;
  }

  try {
    const { error } = await auth.signUp({
      email: email.value,
      password: password.value,
    });
    email.value = '';
    password.value = '';
    confirmPassword.value = '';

    if (error) throw error;
  } catch (error) {
    errorMsg.value = error.message;
    setTimeout(() => {
      errorMsg.value = '';
    }, 3000);
  }
};
</script>

children.value: Finally, we are going to create a
that will take us to the index page if the user is created.

props.code:
<script setup>
// Some code

watchEffect(() => {
  if (user.value) {
    return navigateTo('/');
  }
});
</script>

children.value: Everything together should look like this:

props.code:
<script setup>
const user = useSupabaseUser();
const email = ref('');
const password = ref('');
const confirmPassword = ref('');
const errorMsg = ref('');

const { auth } = useSupabaseClient();
const userRegister = async () => {
  if (password.value !== confirmPassword.value) {
    errorMsg.value = 'Passwords do not match!';
    password.value = '';
    confirmPassword.value = '';
    setTimeout(() => {
      errorMsg.value = '';
    }, 3000);
    return;
  }

  try {
    const { error } = await auth.signUp({
      email: email.value,
      password: password.value,
    });
    email.value = '';
    password.value = '';
    confirmPassword.value = '';

    if (error) throw error;
  } catch (error) {
    errorMsg.value = error.message;
    setTimeout(() => {
      errorMsg.value = '';
    }, 3000);
  }
};

watchEffect(() => {
  if (user.value) {
    return navigateTo('/');
  }
});
</script>

children.value: Supabase automatically logs in the new user when we create it.
The template tag inside the register page
Now we need to create the template tag with the registration form (with
classes) that is going to run the
function when we submit it, we also need to add the
respectively, and a little notification card that is going to let us know if there are any errors.
container mx-auto flex flex-wrap items-center justify-center px-5 py-24 text-gray-400
bg-opacity-50 mt-10 flex w-full flex-col rounded-lg bg-[#242424] p-8 md:mt-0 md:w-1/2 lg:w-2/6

bg-opacity-20 w-full rounded border border-gray-600 bg-transparent py-1 px-3 text-base leading-8 text-gray-100 outline-none transition-colors duration-200 ease-in-out focus:border-[#42d392] focus:bg-transparent focus:ring-2 focus:ring-transparent

bg-opacity-20 w-full rounded border border-gray-600 bg-transparent py-1 px-3 text-base leading-8 text-gray-100 outline-none transition-colors duration-200 ease-in-out focus:border-[#42d392] focus:bg-transparent focus:ring-2 focus:ring-transparent

bg-opacity-20 w-full rounded border border-gray-600 bg-transparent py-1 px-3 text-base leading-8 text-gray-100 outline-none transition-colors duration-200 ease-in-out focus:border-[#42d392] focus:bg-transparent focus:ring-2 focus:ring-transparent
rounded border-0 bg-[#42b883] py-2 px-8 font-sans font-bold text-[#213547] transition-colors duration-500 hover:bg-[#42d392] focus:outline-none
bg-opacity-50 absolute right-8 top-8 rounded-lg bg-[#242424] p-8 px-4 py-2 text-red-500
Log in with an existing user
Now that we have a user created we need a login page. Like the previous pages we are going to start with the
tag. We are going to bring the same things in our state except for the

props.code:
<script setup>
const user = useSupabaseUser();
const email = ref('');
const password = ref('');
const errorMsg = ref('');
const { auth } = useSupabaseClient();
</script>

children.value: Now we need to create the
asynchronous function that is going to run a
method from auth and use the
state as parameters. Then it’s going to clear the fields and also it will display an error message if there are any of them.

props.code:
<script setup>
// Some code

const userLogin = async () => {
  try {
    const { error } = await auth.signIn({
      email: email.value,
      password: password.value,
    });

    email.value = '';
    password.value = '';

    if (error) throw error;
  } catch (error) {
    errorMsg.value = error.message;
    setTimeout(() => {
      errorMsg.value = '';
    }, 3000);
  }
};
</script>

children.value: Lastly, we are going to add the same
that will take us to the index page when we are logged in.

props.code:
<script setup>
// Some code

watchEffect(() => {
  if (user.value) {
    return navigateTo('/');
  }
});
</script>

<script setup>
const user = useSupabaseUser();
const email = ref('');
const password = ref('');
const errorMsg = ref('');
const { auth } = useSupabaseClient();

const userLogin = async () => {
  try {
    const { error } = await auth.signIn({
      email: email.value,
      password: password.value,
    });

    email.value = '';
    password.value = '';

    if (error) throw error;
  } catch (error) {
    errorMsg.value = error.message;
    setTimeout(() => {
      errorMsg.value = '';
    }, 3000);
  }
};

watchEffect(() => {
  if (user.value) {
    return navigateTo('/');
  }
});
</script>

children.value: The template tag inside the login page
The template tag for this page is going to be pretty similar to the registration form but we get rid of the confirmPassword field and it’s going to run the userLogin function instead.
container mx-auto flex flex-wrap items-center justify-center px-5 py-24 text-gray-400
bg-opacity-50 mt-10 flex w-full flex-col rounded-lg bg-[#242424] p-8 md:mt-0 md:w-1/2 lg:w-2/6

bg-opacity-20 w-full rounded border border-gray-600 bg-transparent py-1 px-3 text-base leading-8 text-gray-100 outline-none transition-colors duration-200 ease-in-out focus:border-[#42b883] focus:bg-transparent focus:ring-2 focus:ring-transparent

bg-opacity-20 w-full rounded border border-gray-600 bg-transparent py-1 px-3 text-base leading-8 text-gray-100 outline-none transition-colors duration-200 ease-in-out focus:border-[#42b883] focus:bg-transparent focus:ring-2 focus:ring-transparent
rounded border-0 bg-[#42b883] py-2 px-8 font-sans font-bold text-[#213547] transition-colors duration-500 hover:bg-[#42d392] focus:outline-none
bg-opacity-50 absolute right-8 top-8 rounded-lg bg-[#242424] p-8 px-4 py-2 text-red-500
In order to get redirected if the user is not logged in, we need to create a
folder in the root directory and create an
Inside this file, we are going to add the following code that is going to validate if the user object from supabase has a value and if not is going to take us to the login page.
Now we can run our dev server with npm
Now you are ready to add this feature to any existing or new
app to add authentication very easily.

contents.title: How to add form validation to your Nuxt 3 application
contents.description: When it comes to form validation I think it is better if we handle it on our own with custom validations and error messages. In this post, we will see how to create custom form validations with vuelidate an open source library create for this.

children.value: has its own form validation, I think it is better if we handle it on our own with custom validations and error messages. In this post, we will see how to create custom form validations with
, an open-source library created for these situations.
yet, it’s a lightweight model-based validation library for the
ecosystem, is considered model-based because the validation rules are defined next to your data, and the validation tree structure matches the data model structure.
We are going to start off by installing a couple of dependencies:

props.code: npm install @vuelidate/core @vuelidate/validators

children.value: to run the validation function and the
to add our validations and messages.
for this example we are going to install it along with the

props.code: npm install –save-dev @nuxtjs/tailwindcss nuxt-icon

children.value: Then we need to add the
and the nuxt-icons modules to our
Now we will create a basic form template with some
utility classes to style this a little bit.
bg-opacity-50 mx-auto mt-10 flex w-full flex-col rounded-lg bg-[#242424] p-8 shadow-lg md:mt-0 md:w-1/2 lg:w-2/6

bg-opacity-20 w-full rounded border border-gray-600 bg-transparent py-1 px-3 text-base leading-8 text-gray-100 outline-none transition-colors duration-200 ease-in-out placeholder:text-gray-500 focus:border-blue-500 focus:bg-transparent focus:ring-2 focus:ring-transparent

bg-opacity-20 w-full rounded border border-gray-600 bg-transparent py-1 px-3 text-base leading-8 text-gray-100 outline-none transition-colors duration-200 ease-in-out focus:border-blue-500 focus:bg-transparent focus:ring-2 focus:ring-transparent

bg-opacity-20 w-full rounded border border-gray-600 bg-transparent py-1 px-3 text-base leading-8 text-gray-100 outline-none transition-colors duration-200 ease-in-out focus:border-blue-500 focus:bg-transparent focus:ring-2 focus:ring-transparent
rounded border-0 bg-blue-500 py-2 px-8 font-bold text-[#213547] transition-colors duration-500 hover:bg-blue-600 focus:outline-none
We need to define the data that we need to bind to our form and for that, we are going to create a reactive object with the email, password, and password confirmation properties
After that, we can bind the state data for each input with the v-model directive
Once we have this, we can create the rules that need to match our state. We need to go ahead and import the
function along with the validators we are going to use in this example. Now we can create a rules variable that is going to be equal to a
property that returns an object with the same state properties and also we include the corresponding validators.
We can go further if we also import the
so we can add custom messages with the
The password confirmation field is required
In order to run our validations we need to use the
and we do that by creating a variable named
(by convention) and passing the rules and the state as the parameters.

props.code:
import { useVuelidate } from '@vuelidate/core';

const v$ = useVuelidate(rules, formData);

children.value: We can validate all the fields at once when we submit the form but I also prefer to validate each field individually in order to notify the user about any errors before we submit the form and for that, we can use the $touch method from vuelidate along with the field name and validate it after a change event.

props.code:
<input
  v-model="formData.email"
  type="text"
  id="email"
  name="email"
  placeholder="e.g. example@email.com"
  @change="v$.email.$touch"
/>

children.value: CSS classes depending on the validation result
We can also bind some classes to our input field with the
attribute depending on the output of the validation using green if the field is correct or red if we need to correct something.

props.code:
<input
  class="bg-opacity-20 w-full rounded border border-gray-600 bg-transparent py-1 px-3 text-base leading-8 text-gray-100 outline-none transition-colors duration-200 ease-in-out placeholder:text-gray-500 focus:border-blue-500 focus:bg-transparent focus:ring-2 focus:ring-transparent"
  :class="{
    'border-red-500 focus:border-red-500': v$.email.$error,
    'border-[#42d392] ': !v$.email.$invalid,
  }"
/>

children.value: bg-opacity-20 w-full rounded border border-gray-600 bg-transparent py-1 px-3 text-base leading-8 text-gray-100 outline-none transition-colors duration-200 ease-in-out placeholder:text-gray-500 focus:border-blue-500 focus:bg-transparent focus:ring-2 focus:ring-transparent
Showing the corresponding icon depending on the validation result
We can use the same method to render the corresponding icon if the validation went right or if it went wrong.

bg-opacity-20 w-full rounded border border-gray-600 bg-transparent py-1 px-3 text-base leading-8 text-gray-100 outline-none transition-colors duration-200 ease-in-out placeholder:text-gray-500 focus:border-blue-500 focus:bg-transparent focus:ring-2 focus:ring-transparent
<!-- The icon is going to render but the name of the icon it will depend on the validation output and the color as well -->
And depending on the output it should look like one of these examples:
Run our validations before we submit the form
Finally, run our validations when the form is submitted with the
method and we can run the submission logic if there was any errors in our validations.

Once you made this validation login form you should be able to re-use this code for all of your forms that need validation or simply use it when you need to validate any input field in your application and you can get help by checking the docs.
You can find the source code from my Github
Learn more about the Vuelidate library in the docs

contents.title: What are the differences between client side rendering, server side rendering and static site generation
contents.description: Unsure which method of rendering is best for your website? Read this blog post on the differences between client-side rendering, server-side rendering, and static site generation to make an informed decision.

children.value: There are several ways to deliver content to users on the web, and each method has its own set of benefits and drawbacks. In this post, we'll explore the differences between client-side rendering, server-side rendering, and static site generation, and help you understand which approach might be the best fit for your project.

Client-side rendering, also known as "dynamic rendering" refers to the process of rendering web pages on the client-side, or in the user's web browser. This is the most common method of rendering content on the web, and it is used by most websites and web applications.

In client-side rendering, the browser sends a request to the server for a webpage, and the server responds with an HTML file that includes a reference to a JavaScript file. The browser then loads the JavaScript file, which is responsible for rendering the content of the page. This means that the content of the page is not actually present in the HTML file that is initially sent by the server. Instead, it is generated by the JavaScript code that runs in the browser.

One advantage of client-side rendering is that it allows for a more interactive and dynamic user experience. Because the content is generated on the client-side, it can be easily updated and changed in real-time without the need to reload the page. This can be especially useful for web applications that need to display frequently updating data, such as social media feeds or real-time stock tickers.

However, client-side rendering also has some drawbacks. Because the content is generated by JavaScript, it can take longer for the page to load, as the browser has to download and execute the JavaScript code before it can display the content. This can lead to slower page load times, which can be frustrating for users and may negatively impact search engine rankings. Additionally, because the content is not present in the initial HTML file, it is not visible to search engines, which can make it more difficult for the page to be indexed and rank well in search results.

Server-side rendering (SSR) is a method of rendering web pages in which the server generates the full HTML for a page and sends it to the client as a complete document. This approach to rendering has been the traditional way of building web pages since the early days of the web and is still widely used today.

One of the primary benefits of server-side rendering is improved search engine optimization (SEO). Since search engines rely on server-side rendering to crawl and index web pages, SSR can help ensure that your content is fully discoverable and easily indexed. Additionally, SSR can help improve the accessibility and performance of your site, especially for users with slower internet connections or less powerful devices.

Another advantage of server-side rendering is that it can provide a more consistent user experience across different devices and browsers. By generating the full HTML on the server, developers can ensure that the content is rendered consistently across different platforms and devices, without relying on client-side processing or browser-specific code.

However, there are also several drawbacks to server-side rendering. One of the main challenges is that it can result in slower load times for the initial page load, especially for more complex web applications. Additionally, SSR can be more difficult to implement than client-side rendering, especially for large or complex applications that require a lot of server-side processing.

Another issue with SSR is that it can be less flexible and customizable than client-side rendering. Since the full HTML is generated on the server, it can be more difficult to create highly dynamic or interactive user interfaces that rely heavily on client-side processing and JavaScript.

Static site generation (SSG) is a method of building websites in which the content is pre-rendered and served as static files, rather than being generated dynamically on the server. This approach to web development has gained popularity in recent years due to its simplicity, security, and performance benefits.

One of the primary advantages of static site generation is speed. Since the content is pre-built and served as static files, there is no need for server-side processing or database interactions, resulting in faster load times and improved performance. Additionally, static sites are often more secure than dynamic sites, since there is no server-side processing or database interaction that can be vulnerable to attack.

Another benefit of SSG is ease of deployment and scalability. Since the content is pre-built and served as static files, it is easy to deploy to a variety of hosting platforms and scale to meet the needs of a growing user base.

However, there are also some drawbacks to static site generation. One of the main challenges is that it can be more difficult to create highly dynamic or interactive web applications that require real-time processing or user interactions. Additionally, SSG may not be suitable for applications that require frequent updates or content changes.

Another potential issue with SSG is that it may require more technical expertise to set up and maintain than other web development approaches. Developers need to be proficient in tools and workflows such as version control, automated testing, and continuous integration and deployment.

In conclusion, when deciding between client-side rendering, server-side rendering, and static site generation for your next project, it's important to consider the specific needs and requirements of your application.

Client-side rendering can provide a highly dynamic and interactive user experience, but may be slower to load and less optimized for search engines. Server-side rendering can improve SEO, accessibility, and consistency across different devices and browsers, but may be slower to load and more difficult to implement. Static site generation can provide significant speed, security, and scalability benefits, but may not be suitable for highly dynamic or interactive applications.

Ultimately, the choice between these different rendering approaches will depend on factors such as the size and complexity of your application, the level of interactivity and real-time processing required, and your overall development and hosting resources.

When choosing which approach to use, it's important to consider not only the immediate needs of your project, but also its long-term scalability and maintenance requirements. By carefully weighing the pros and cons of each approach and selecting the one that best meets the needs of your application and its users, you can ensure a successful and sustainable project that delivers an exceptional user experience.
